ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course was different from any other course I have ever taken. I learned how to analyze and think in a completely new and interesting way. I learned how to apply computerized systems to real life situations.
I learned a lot about social networks from an analytical perspective, as well as a broad but detailed framework about the intersection and implications of computing and society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Boorman's lecture notes were sent in email format. It would've been helpful if they were in a file format or on Canvas.
I think sometimes a walkthrough the readings could be a help improve understanding of the material.

There is a lot of content in this course--too much to sum up briefly--but I found that the material provided for each class was surprising well-curated and interesting to read. I also enjoyed Professor Boorman's lectures, although they might not suit everyone since there is not much room for class discussion. In terms of improvements, maybe providing a discussion board for the topics we discuss would help with engagement. I would also suggest formatting the emails as a newsletter and / or having a simple website to centralize all the information.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would. I think this course is a great and different introduction to the study of social sciences.

Take this course, but mainly if you are already interested in the material! It is low workload, and I think Professor Boorman teaches the material well, but if you aren't willing to engage with the material outside of or during class you probably will not get much out of the course.
